intro: Draba fladnizensis var. carinthiaca, commonly known as the Carinthian whitlow grass, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the alpine regions of the Eastern Alps. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically thrives in rocky or gravelly soils at high altitudes, where it forms dense mats. Its leaves are basal, linear, and covered in a fine pubescence, while its flowers are white or pale yellow. This variety is notable for its ecological role in stabilizing alpine soils and supporting specialized insect pollinators.
